verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 1:1
verses.text: Concerning Virgins, Book III:  Chapter I.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 1:2
verses.text: St.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 1:3
verses.text: Ambrose now goes back to the address of Liberius when he gave the veil to Marcellina.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 1:4
verses.text: Touching on the crowds pressing to the bridal feast of that Spouse Who feeds them all, he passes on to the fitness of her profession on the day on which Christ was born of a Virgin, and concludes with a fervent exhortation to love Him.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 1:6
verses.text: Inasmuch as I have digressed in what I have said in the two former hooks, it is now time, holy sister, to reconsider those precepts of Liberius of blessed memory which you used to talk over with me, as the holier the man the more pleasing is his discourse.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 1:7
verses.text: For he, when on the Nativity of the Saviour in the Church of St.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 1:8
verses.text: Peter you signified your profession of virginity by your change of attire (and what day could be better than that on which the Virgin received her child?) whilst many virgins were standing round and vying with each other for your companionship.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 1:9
verses.text: "You," said he, "my daughter, have desired a good espousal.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 1:10
verses.text: You see how great a crowd has come together for the birthday of your Spouse, and none has gone away without food.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 1:11
verses.text: This is He, Who, when invited to the marriage feast, changed water into wine.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 1:12
verses.text: He, too, will confer the pure sacrament of virginity on you who before were subject to the vile elements of material nature.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 1:13
verses.text: This is He Who fed four thousand in the wilderness with five loaves and two fishes".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 1:14
verses.text: He could have fed more; if more had been there to be fed, they would have been.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 1:15
verses.text: And now He has called many to your espousal, but it is not now barley bread, but the Body from heaven which is supplied.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 1:17
verses.text: To-day, indeed, He was born after the manner of men, of a Virgin, but was begotten of the Father before all things, resembling His mother in body, His Father in power.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 1:18
verses.text: Only-begotten on earth, and Only-begotten in heaven.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 1:19
verses.text: God of God, born of a Virgin, Righteousness from the Father, Power from the Mighty One, Light of Light, not unequal to His Father; nor separated in power, not confused by extension of the Word or enlargement as though mingled with the Father, but distinguished from the Father by virtue of His generation.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 1:20
verses.text: He is your Brother, without Whom neither things in heaven, nor things in the sea, nor things on earth consist.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 1:21
verses.text: The good Word of the Father, Which was, it is said, "in the beginning," here you have His eternity.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 1:22
verses.text: "And," it is said, "the Word was with God".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 1:23
verses.text: Here you have His power, undivided and inseparable from the Father.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 1:24
verses.text: "And the Word was God".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 1:25
verses.text: Here you have His unbegotten Godhead, for your faith is to be drawn from the mutual relationship.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 1:27
verses.text: Love him, my daughter, for He is good.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 1:28
verses.text: For, "None is good save God only".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 1:29
verses.text: For if there be no doubt that the Son is God, and that God is good, there is certainly no doubt that God the Son is good.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 1:30
verses.text: Love Him I say.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 1:31
verses.text: He it is Whom the Father begat before the morning star, as being eternal, He brought Him forth from the womb as the Son; He uttered him from His heart, as the Word.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 1:32
verses.text: He it is in Whom the Father is well pleased; He is the Arm of the Father, for He is Creator of all, and the Wisdom of the Father, for He proceeded from the mouth of God; the Power of the Father, because the fulness of the Godhead dwelleth in Him bodily.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 1:33
verses.text: And the Father so loved Him, as to bear Him in His bosom, and place Him at His right hand, that you may learn His wisdom, and know His power.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 1:35
verses.text: If, then, Christ is the Power of God, was God ever without power? Was the Father ever without the Son? If the Father of a certainty always was, of a certainty the Son always was.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 1:36
verses.text: So He is the perfect Son of a perfect Father.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 1:37
verses.text: For he who derogates from the power, derogates from Him Whose is the power.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 1:38
verses.text: The Perfection of the Godhead does not admit of inequality.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 1:39
verses.text: Love, then, Him Whom the Father loves, honour Him Whom the Father honours, for "he that honoureth not the Son, honoureth not the Father," and "whoso denieth the Son, hath not the Father".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 1:40
verses.text: So much as to the faith.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 2:1
verses.text: Chapter II.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 2:2
verses.text: Touching next upon the training of a virgin, he speaks of moderation in food and drink, and of restraint upon the impulses of the mind, introducing some teaching upon the fable of the death and resurrection of Hippolytus, and advises the avoidance of certain meats.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 2:4
verses.text: But sometimes even when faith is to be relied upon, youth is not trusted.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 2:5
verses.text: Use wine, therefore, sparingly, in order that the weakness of the body may not increase, not for pleasurable excitement, for each alike kindles a flame, both wine and youth.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 2:6
verses.text: Let fasts also put a bridle on tender age, and spare diet restrain the unsubdued appetites with a kind of rein.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 2:7
verses.text: Let reason check, hope subdue, and fear curb them.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 2:8
verses.text: For he who knows not how to govern his desires, like a man run away with by wild horses, is overthrown, bruised, torn, and injured.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 2:10
verses.text: And this is said to have happened to a youth for his love of Diana.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 2:11
verses.text: But the fable is coloured with poet's tales, that Neptune, stirred with grief at his rival being preferred, sent madness upon his horses, whereby his great power might be set forth in that he overcame the youth, not by strength, but by fraud.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 2:12
verses.text: And from this event a yearly sacrifice is celebrated for Diana, when a horse is offered at her altar.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 2:13
verses.text: And they say that she was a virgin, and (of which even harlots would be ashamed) yet could love one who did not love her.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 2:14
verses.text: But as far as I am concerned let their fables have authority, for though each be criminal, it is yet a less evil that a youth should have been so enamoured of an adulteress as to perish, than that two gods should, as they relate, contend for committing adultery, and that Jupiter avenged the grief of his daughter who played the harlot on the physician who cured the wound of him who had violated Diana in the woods, a most excellent huntress, no doubt, not of wild beasts, but of lust: yet also of wild beasts, so that she was worshipped naked.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 2:16
verses.text: Let them ascribe, then, to Neptune the mastery over madness, in order to fix on him the crime of unchaste love.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 2:17
verses.text: Let them ascribe to Diana the rule over the woods, wherein she dwelt, so as to establish the adultery which she practised.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 2:18
verses.text: Let them ascribe to aesculapius the restoration of the dead so long as they confess that when struck by lightning he himself escaped not.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 2:19
verses.text: Let them also ascribe to Jupiter the thunderbolts which he did not possess, so that they witness to the disgrace with which he was laden.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 2:21
verses.text: And I think that one should sparingly eat all kinds of food which cause heat to the limbs, for flesh drags down even eagles as they fly.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 2:22
verses.text: But within you let that bird of which we read, "Thy youth shall be renewed like the eagle's," holding its course on high, swift in its virgin flight, be ignorant of the desire for unnecessary food.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 2:23
verses.text: The gathering of banquets and salutations must be avoided.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 3:1
verses.text: Chapter III.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 3:2
verses.text: Virgins are exhorted to avoid visits, to observe modesty, to be silent during the celebration of the Mysteries after the example of Mary.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 3:3
verses.text: Then after narrating the story of a heathen youth, and saying of a poet, St.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 3:4
verses.text: Ambrose relates a miracle wrought by a holy priest.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 3:6
verses.text: I will, too, that visits amongst the younger, except such as may be due to parents and those of like age, be few.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 3:7
verses.text: For modesty is worn away by intercourse, and boldness breaks forth, laughter creeps in, and bashfulness is lessened, whilst politeness is studied.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 3:8
verses.text: Not to answer one who asks a question is childishness, to answer is nonsense.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 3:9
verses.text: I should prefer, therefore, that conversation should rather be wanting to a virgin, than abound.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 3:10
verses.text: For if women are bidden to keep silence in churches, even about divine things, and to ask their husbands at home, what do we think should be the caution of virgins, in whom modesty adorns their age, and silence commends their modesty.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 3:12
verses.text: Was it a small sign of modesty that when Rebecca came to wed Isaac, and saw her bridegroom, she took a veil, that she might not be seen before they were united? Certainly the fair virgin feared not for her beauty, but for her modesty.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 3:13
verses.text: What of Rachel, how she, when Jacob's kiss had been taken, wept and groaned, and would not have ceased weeping had she not known him to be a kinsman? So she both observed what was due to modesty, and omitted not kindly affection.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 3:14
verses.text: But if it is said to a man: "Gaze not on a maid, lest she cause thee to fall," what is to be said to a consecrated virgin, who, if she loves, sins in mind; if she is loved, in act also?  11.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 3:15
verses.text: The virtue of silence, especially in Church, is very great.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 3:16
verses.text: Let no sentence of the divine lessons escape you; if you give ear, restrain your voice, utter no word with your lips which you would wish to recall,  but let your boldness to speak be sparing.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 3:17
verses.text: For in truth in much speaking there is abundance of sin.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 3:18
verses.text: To the murderer it was said: "Thou hast sinned, be silent," that he might not sin more; but to the virgin it must be said, "Be silent lest thou sin".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 3:19
verses.text: For Mary, as we read, kept in heart all things that were said concerning her Son, and do you, when any passage is read where Christ is announced as about to come, or is shown to have come, not make a noise by talking, but attend.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 3:20
verses.text: Is anything more unbecoming than the divine words should be so drowned by talking, as not to be heard, believed, or made known, that the sacraments should be indistinctly heard through the sound of voices, that prayer should be hindered when offered for the salvation of all?  12.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 3:21
verses.text: The Gentiles pay respect to their idols by silence, of which this instance is given: As Alexander, the king of the Macedonians, was sacrificing, the sleeve of a barbarian lad who was lighting the lamp for him caught fire and burnt his body, yet he remained without moving and neither betrayed the pain by a groan, nor showed his suffering by silent tears.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 3:22
verses.text: Such was the discipline of reverence in a barbarian lad that nature was subdued.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 3:23
verses.text: Yet he feared not the gods, who were no gods, but the king.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 3:24
verses.text: For why should he fear those who if the same fire had caught them would have burnt?  13.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 3:25
verses.text: How much better still is it where a youth at his father's banquet is bidden not to betray by coarse gestures his unchaste loves.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 3:26
verses.text: And do you, holy virgin, abstain from groans, cries, coughing, and laughter at the Mystery.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 3:27
verses.text: Can you not at the Mystery do what he did at a banquet? Let virginity be first marked by the voice, let modesty close the mouth, let religion remove weakness, and habit instruct nature.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 3:28
verses.text: Let her gravity first announce a virgin to me, a modest approach, a sober gait, a bashful countenance, and let the march of virtue be preceded by the evidence of integrity.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 3:29
verses.text: That virgin is not sufficiently worthy of approval who has to be enquired about when she is seen.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 3:31
verses.text: There is common story how, when the excessive croaking of frogs was resounding in the ears of the faithful people, the priest of God bade them be silent, and show reverence to the sacred words, and then at once the noise was stilled.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 3:32
verses.text: Shall then the marshes keep silence and not the frogs? And shall irrational animals re-acknowledge by reverence what they know not by nature? While the shamelessness of men is such, that many care not to pay that respect to the religious feelings of their minds, which they do to the pleasure of their ears.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 4:1
verses.text: Chapter IV.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 4:2
verses.text: Having summed up the address of Liberius, St.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 4:3
verses.text: Ambrose passes on to the virtues of his sister, especially her fasts, which however he advises her to moderate to some extent, and to exercise herself in other matters, after the example which he adduces.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 4:4
verses.text: Especially he recommends the Lord's Prayer, and the repetition of Psalms by night, and the recitation of the Creed before daylight.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 4:6
verses.text: After such a fashion did Liberius of holy memory address you, in words beyond the reality of practice in most cases, but coming short of your performance, who have not only attained to the whole of discipline by your virtue, but have surpassed it in your zeal.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 4:7
verses.text: For we are bidden to practise fasting, but only for single days; but you, multiplying nights and days, pass untold periods without food, and if ever requested to partake of some, and to lay aside your book a little while, you at once answer: "Man doth not live by bread alone, but by every word of God".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 4:8
verses.text: Your very meals consisted but of what food came to hand, so that fasting is to be preferred to eating what was repugnant; your drink is from the spring, your weeping and prayer combine, your sleep is on your book.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 4:10
verses.text: These kings were suited to younger years, whilst he was ripening with the gray hairs of age; but when a virgin has gained the triumph over her subdued body, she should lessen her toil, that she may be preserved as teacher for a younger age.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 4:11
verses.text: The vine laden with the fruitful branches of full growth soon breaks unless it be from time to time kept back.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 4:12
verses.text: But whilst it is young let it grow rank, and as it grows older be pruned, so as not to grow into a forest of twigs, or die deprived of life by its exceptive produce.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 4:13
verses.text: A good husbandman by tending the soil keeps the vine in excellent order, protects it from cold, and guards it from being parched by the mid-day sun.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 4:14
verses.text: And he works his land by turns, or if he will not let it lie fallow, he alternates his crops, so that the fields may rest through change of produce.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 4:15
verses.text: Do you too, a veteran in virginity, at least sow the fields of your breast with different seeds, at one time with moderate sustenance, at another with sparing fasts,  with reading, work, and prayer, that change of toil may be as a truce for rest.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 4:17
verses.text: The whole land does not produce the same harvest.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 4:18
verses.text: On one side vines grow on the hills, on another you can see the purple olives, elsewhere the scented roses.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 4:19
verses.text: And after leaving the plough, the strong husbandman with his fingers scrapes the soil to plant the roots of flowers, and with the rough hands wherewith he turns the bullocks striving amongst the vines, he gently presses the udders of the sheep.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 4:20
verses.text: The land is the better the more numerous are its fruits.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 4:21
verses.text: So do you, following the example of a good husbandman, avoid cleaving your soil with perpetual fastings as if with deep ploughings.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 4:22
verses.text: Let the rose of modesty bloom in your garden, and the lily of the mind, and let the violet beds drink from the source of sacred blood.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 4:23
verses.text: There is a common saying, "What you wish to perform abundantly, sometimes do not do at all".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 4:24
verses.text: There ought to be something to add to the days of Lent, but so that nothing be done for the sake of ostentation, but of religion.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 4:26
verses.text: Frequent prayer also commends us to God.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 4:27
verses.text: For if the prophet says, "Seven times a day have I praised Thee," though he was busy with the affairs of a kingdom, what ought we to do, who read: "Watch and pray that ye enter not into temptation"? Certainly our customary prayers ought to be said with giving of thanks, when we rise from sleep, when we go forth, when we prepare to receive food, after receiving it, and at the hour of incense, when at last we are going to rest.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 4:29
verses.text: And again in your bed-chamber itself, I would have you join psalms in frequent interchange with the Lord's prayer, either when you wake up, or before sleep bedews your body, so that at the very commencement of rest sleep may find you free from the care of worldly matters, meditating upon the things of God.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 4:30
verses.text: And, indeed, he who first found out the name of Philosophy itself, every day before he went to rest, had the flute-player play softer melodies to soothe his mind disturbed by worldly cares.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 4:31
verses.text: But he, like a man washing tiles, fruitlessly desired to drive away worldly things by worldly means, for he was, indeed, rather besmearing himself with fresh mud, in seeking a reward from pleasure, but let us, having wiped off the filth of earthly vices, purify our utmost souls from every defilement of the flesh.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 4:33
verses.text: We ought, also, specially to repeat the Creed, as a seal upon our hearts, daily, before light, and to recur to it in thought whenever we are in fear of anything.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 4:34
verses.text: For when is the soldier in his tent or the warrior in battle without his military oath?.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 5:1
verses.text: Chapter V.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 5:2
verses.text: St.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 5:3
verses.text: Ambrose, speaking of tears, explains David's saying, "Every night wash l my couch with my tears," and goes on to speak of Christ bearing our griefs and infirmities.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 5:4
verses.text: Everything should be referred to His honour, and we ought to rejoice with spiritual joy, but not after a worldly fashion.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 5:6
verses.text: And who can now fail to understand that the holy prophet said for our instruction: "Every night will I wash my couch and water my bed with my tears"? For if you take it literally for his bed, he shows that such abundance of tears should be shed as to wash the bed and water it with tears, the couch of him who is praying, for weeping has to do with the present, rewards with the future, since it is said: "Blessed are ye that weep, for ye shall laugh;" or if we take the word of the prophet as applied to our bodies, we must wash away the offences of the body with tears of penitence.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 5:7
verses.text: For Solomon made himself a bed of wood from Lebanon, its pillars were of silver, its bottom of gold, its back strewn with gems.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 5:8
verses.text: What is that bed but the fashion of our body? For by gems is set forth the splendour of the brightness of the air, fire is set forth by the gold, water by silver, and earth by wood, of which four elements the human body consists, in which our soul rests, if it do not exist deprived of rest by the roughness of hills or the damp ground, but raised on high, above vices, supported by the wood.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 5:9
verses.text: For which reason David also says: "The Lord will send him help upon his bed of pain".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 5:10
verses.text: For how can that be a bed of pain which cannot feel pain, and which has no feeling? But the body of pain is like the body of that death, of which it is said: "O wretched man that I am, who shall deliver me from the body of this death?"  22.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 5:11
verses.text: And since I have inserted a clause in which mention is made of the Lord's Body, lest any one should be troubled at reading that the Lord took a body of pain, let him remember that the Lord grieved and wept  over the death of Lazarus, and was wounded in His passion, and that from the wound there went forth blood and water, and that He gave up His Spirit.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 5:12
verses.text: Water for washing, Blood for drink, the Spirit for His rising again.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 5:13
verses.text: For Christ alone is to us hope, faith, and love—hope in His resurrection, faith in the laver, and love in the sacrament.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 5:15
verses.text: And as He took a body of pain, so too He turned His bed in His weakness, for He converted it to the benefit of human flesh.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 5:16
verses.text: For by His Passion weakness was ended, and death by His resurrection.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 5:17
verses.text: And yet you ought to mourn for the world but to rejoice in the Lord, to be sad for penitence but joyful for grace, though, too, the teacher of the Gentiles by a wholesome precept has bidden to weep with them that weep, and to rejoice with them that do rejoice.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 5:19
verses.text: But let him who desires to solve the whole difficulty of this question have recourse to the same Apostle.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 5:20
verses.text: "Whatsoever ye do," says he, "in word or deed, do all in the Name of our Lord Jesus Christ, giving thanks to God the Father by Him".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 5:21
verses.text: Let us then refer all our words and deeds to Christ, Who brought life out of death, and created light out of darkness.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 5:22
verses.text: For as a sick body is at one time cherished by warmth, at another soothed by cool applications, and the variation of remedies, if carried out according to the direction of the physician, is healthful, but if done in opposition to his orders increases the sickness; so whatever is paid to Christ is a remedy, whatever is done by our own will is harmful.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 5:24
verses.text: There ought then to be the joy of the mind, conscious of right, not excited by unrestrained feasts, or nuptial concerts, for in such modesty is not safe, and temptation may be suspected where excessive dancing accompanies festivities.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 5:25
verses.text: I desire that the virgins of God should be far from this.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 5:26
verses.text: For as a certain teacher of this world has said: "No one dances when sober unless he is mad".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 5:27
verses.text: Now if, according to the wisdom of this world, either drunkenness or madness is the cause of dancing, what a warning is given to us amongst the instances mentioned in the Divine Scriptures, where John, the forerunner of Christ, being beheaded at the wish of a dancer, is an instance that the allurements of dancing did more harm than the madness of sacrilegious anger.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 6:1
verses.text: Chapter VI.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 6:2
verses.text: Having mentioned the Baptist, St.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 6:3
verses.text: Ambrose enters into a description of the events concerning his death, and speaks against dancing and the festivities of the wicked.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 6:5
verses.text: And since we must not cursorily pass by the mention of so great a man, let us consider who he was, by whom, on what account, how, and at what time he was slain.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 6:6
verses.text: A just man, he is put to death by adulterers, and the penalty of a capital crime is turned off by the guilty on to the judge.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 6:7
verses.text: Again the reward of the dancer is the death of the prophet.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 6:8
verses.text: Lastly (a matter of honour even to all barbarians), the cruel sentence is given in the midst of banqueting and festivities, and the news of the deadly crime is carried from the banquet to the prison, and then from the prison to the banquet.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 6:9
verses.text: How many crimes are there in one wicked act!  27.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 6:10
verses.text: A banquet of death is set out with royal luxury, and when a larger concourse than usual had come together, the daughter of the queen, sent for from within the private apartments, is brought forth to dance in the sight of men.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 6:11
verses.text: What could she have learnt from an adulteress but loss of modesty? Is anything so conducive to lust as with unseemly movements thus to expose in nakedness those parts of the body which either nature has hidden or custom has veiled, to sport with the looks, to turn the neck, to loosen the hair? Fitly was the next step an offence against God.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 6:12
verses.text: For what modesty can there be where there is dancing and noise and clapping of hands?  28.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 6:13
verses.text: "Then," it is said, "the king being pleased, said unto the damsel, that she should ask of the king whatsoever she would.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 6:14
verses.text: Then he swore that if she asked he would give her even the half of his kingdom".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 6:15
verses.text: See how worldly men themselves judge of their worldly power, so as to give even kingdoms for dancing.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 6:16
verses.text: But the damsel, being taught by her mother, demanded that the head of John should be brought to her on a dish.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 6:17
verses.text: That which is said that "the king was sorry," is not repentance on the part of the king, but a confession of guilt, which is, according to the wont of the divine rule, that they who have done evil condemn themselves by their own confession.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 6:18
verses.text: "But for their sakes which sat with him," it is said.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 6:19
verses.text: What is more base than that a murder should be committed in order  not to displease those who sat at meat? "And," it follows, "for his oath's sake".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 6:20
verses.text: What a new religion! He had better have forsworn himself.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 6:21
verses.text: The Lord therefore in the Gospel bids us not to swear at all, that there be no cause for perjury, and no need of offending.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 6:22
verses.text: And so an innocent man is slain that an oath be not violated.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 6:23
verses.text: I know which to have in the greatest horror.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 6:24
verses.text: Perjury is more endurable than are the oaths of tyrants.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 6:26
verses.text: Who would not think when he saw some one running from the banquet to the prison, that orders had been given to set the prophet free? Who, I say, having heard that it was Herod's birthday, and of the state banquet, and the choice given to the damsel of choosing whatever she wished, would not think that the man was sent to set John free? What has cruelty in common with delicacies? What have death and pleasure in common? The prophet is hurried to suffer at a festal time by a festal order, by which he would even wish to be set free; he is slain by the sword, and his head is brought on a platter.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 6:27
verses.text: This dish was well suited to their cruelty, in order that their insatiate savageness might be feasted.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 6:29
verses.text: Look, most savage king, at the sights worthy of thy feast.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 6:30
verses.text: Stretch forth thy right hand, that nothing be wanting to thy cruelty, that streams of holy blood may pour down between thy fingers.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 6:31
verses.text: And since the hunger for such unheard-of cruelty could not be satisfied by banquets, nor the thirst by goblets, drink the blood pouring from the still flowing veins of the cut-off head.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 6:32
verses.text: Behold those eyes, even in death, the witnesses of thy crime, turning away from the sight of the delicacies.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 6:33
verses.text: The eyes are closing, not so much owing to death, as to horror of luxury.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 6:34
verses.text: That bloodless golden mouth, whose sentence thou couldst not endure, is silent, and yet thou fearest.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 6:35
verses.text: Yet the tongue, which even after death is wont to observe its duty as when living, condemned, though with trembling motion, the incest.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 6:36
verses.text: This head is borne to Herodias: she rejoices, she exults as though she had escaped from the crime, because she has slain her judge.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 6:38
verses.text: What say you, holy women? Do you see what you ought to teach, and what also to unteach your daughters? She dances, but she is the daughter of an adulteress.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 6:39
verses.text: But she who is modest, she who is chaste, let her teach her daughter religion, not dancing.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 6:40
verses.text: And do you, grave and prudent men, learn to avoid the banquets of hateful men.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 6:41
verses.text: If such are the banquets, what will be the judgment of the impious?.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 7:1
verses.text: Chapter VII.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 7:2
verses.text: In reply to Marcellina, who had asked what should be thought of those who to escape violence killed themselves, St.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 7:3
verses.text: Ambrose replies by narrating the history of Pelagia, a virgin, with her mother and sister, and goes on to speak of the martyrdom of the blessed Sotheris, one of their own ancestors.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 7:5
verses.text: As I am drawing near the close of my address, you make a good suggestion, holy sister, that I should touch upon what we ought to think of the merits of those who have cast themselves down from a height, or have drowned themselves in a river, lest they should fall into the hands of persecutors, seeing that holy Scripture forbids a Christian to lay hands on himself.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 7:6
verses.text: And indeed as regards virgins placed in the necessity of preserving their purity, we have a plain answer, seeing that there exists an instance of martyrdom.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 7:8
verses.text: Saint Pelagia lived formerly at Antioch, being about fifteen years old, a sister of virgins, and a virgin herself.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 7:9
verses.text: She shut herself up at home at the first sound of persecution, seeing herself surrounded by those who would rob her of her faith and purity, in the absence of her mother and sisters, without any defence, but all the more filled with God.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 7:10
verses.text: "What are we to do, unless," says she to herself, "thou, a captive of virginity, takest thought? I both wish and fear to die, for I meet not death but seek it.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 7:11
verses.text: Let us die if we are allowed, or if they will not allow it, still let us die.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 7:12
verses.text: God is not offended by a remedy against evil, and faith permits the act.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 7:13
verses.text: In truth, if we think of the real meaning of the word, how can what is voluntary be violence? It is rather violence to wish to die and not to be able.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 7:14
verses.text: And we do not fear any difficulty.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 7:15
verses.text: For who is there who wishes to die and is not able to do so, when there are so many easy ways to death? For I can now rush upon the sacrilegious altars and overthrow them, and quench with my blood the kindled fires.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 7:16
verses.text: I am not afraid that my right hand may fail to deliver the blow, or that my breast may  shrink from the pain.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 7:17
verses.text: I shall leave no sin to my flesh.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 7:18
verses.text: I fear not that a sword will be wanting.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 7:19
verses.text: I can die by my own weapons, I can die without the help of an executioner, in my mother's bosom".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 7:21
verses.text: She is said to have adorned her head, and to have put on a bridal dress, so that one would say that she was going to a bridegroom, not to death.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 7:22
verses.text: But when the hateful persecutors saw that they had lost the prey of her chastity, they began to seek her mother and sisters.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 7:23
verses.text: But they, by a spiritual flight, already held the field of chastity, when, as on the one side, persecutors suddenly threatened them, and on the other, escape was shut off by an impetuous river, they said, what do we fear? See the water, what hinders us from being baptized? And this is the baptism whereby sins are forgiven, and kingdoms are sought.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 7:24
verses.text: This is a baptism after which no one sins.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 7:25
verses.text: Let the water receive us, which is wont to regenerate.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 7:26
verses.text: Let the water receive us, which makes virgins.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 7:27
verses.text: Let the water receive us, which opens heaven, protects the weak, hides death, makes martyrs.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 7:28
verses.text: We pray Thee, God, Creator of all things, let not the water scatter our bodies, deprived of the breath of life; let not death separate our obsequies, whose lives affection has always conjoined; but let our constancy be one, our death one, and our burial also be one.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 7:30
verses.text: Having said these words, and having slightly girded up the bosom of their dress, to veil their modesty without impeding their steps, joining hands as though to lead a dance, they went forward to the middle of the river bed, directing their steps to where the stream was more violent, and the depth more abrupt.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 7:31
verses.text: No one drew back, no one ceased to go on, no one tried where to place her steps, they were anxious only when they felt the ground, grieved when the water was shallow, and glad when it was deep.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 7:32
verses.text: One could see the pious mother tightening her grasp, rejoicing in her pledges, afraid of a fall lest even the stream should carry off her daughters from her.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 7:33
verses.text: "These victims, O Christ," said she, "do I offer as leaders of chastity, guides on my journey, and companions of my sufferings".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 7:35
verses.text: But who would have cause to wonder that they had such constancy whilst alive, seeing that even when dead they preserved the position of their bodies unmoved? The water did not lay bare their corpses, nor did the rapid course of the river roll them along.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 7:36
verses.text: Moreover, the holy mother, though without sensation, still maintained her loving grasp, and held the sacred knot which she had tied, and loosed not her hold in death, that she who had paid her debt to religion might die leaving her piety as her heir.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 7:37
verses.text: For those whom she had joined together with herself for martyrdom, she claimed even to the tomb.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 7:39
verses.text: But why use instances of people of another race to you, my sister, whom the inspiration of hereditary chastity has taught by descent from a martyred ancestor? For whence have you learnt who had no one from whom to learn, living in the country, with no virgin companion, instructed by no teacher? You have played the part then not of a disciple, for this cannot be done without teaching, but of an heir of virtue.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 7:41
verses.text: For how could it come to pass that holy Sotheris should not have been the originator of your purpose, who is an ancestor of your race? Who, in an age of persecution, borne to the heights of suffering by the insults of slaves, gave to the executioner even her face, which is usually free from injury when the whole body is tortured, and rather beholds than suffers torments; so brave and patient that when she offered her tender cheeks to punishment, the executioner failed in striking before the martyr yielded under the injuries.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 7:42
verses.text: She moved not her face, she turned not away her countenance, she uttered not a groan or a tear.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Virgins Book III 7:43
verses.text: Lastly, when she had overcome other kinds of punishment, she found the sword which she desired.
